maml:description.maml:para: Use this command to check the status of key modules. The command will return a list of modules with their online version, installed version, and whether an update is needed.
The module names to check. The PSReadline and Microsoft.PowerShell.PSResourceGet modules are included by default.
The module names to check. The PSReadline and Microsoft.PowerShell.PSResourceGet modules are included by default.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-ModuleStatus
Name Online Installed UpdateNeeded ---- ------ --------- ------------ PSReadLine 2.4.5 2.4.5 False Microsoft.PowerShell.PSResourceGet 1.1.1 1.1.1 False

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-ModuleStatus -Module Pester,PSReadline,PackageManagement
Name Online Installed UpdateNeeded ---- ------ --------- ------------ Pester 5.7.1 5.7.1 False PSReadLine 2.4.5 2.4.5 False PackageManagement 1.4.8.1 1.4.8.1 False

dev:remarks.maml:para: Check the status of user-specified modules.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-Content C:\scripts\MyModules.txt | Get-ModuleStatus
Name Online Installed UpdateNeeded ---- ------ --------- ------------ Microsoft.PowerShell.ConsoleGuiTools 0.7.7 0.7.7 False Microsoft.PowerShell.Crescendo 1.1.0 1.1.0 False Microsoft.PowerShell.PlatyPS 1.0.1 1.0.1 False Microsoft.PowerShell.PSResourceGet 1.1.1 1.1.1 False Microsoft.WinGet.Client 1.11.460 1.12.350 False Microsoft.PowerShell.WhatsNew 0.5.5 0.5.5 False Microsoft.PowerShell.ThreadJob 2.2.0 2.2.0 False

dev:remarks.maml:para: Check module status from a list.

maml:description.maml:para: This command will display a PowerShell welcome or "splash" screen. The display includes a list of online resources. If you include the -ModuleStatus parameter, the output will include the status of key modules. Keeping these modules up to date will help ensure a good user experience.

If you include -Tutorial, you will be prompted to run a set of tutorials. The tutorials are interactive and will help the user learn about PowerShell. If the user chooses to run the tutorials, they will be run consecutively. The tutorials are written as PowerShell scripts with a combination of formatted text and live console output from the user's session. This ensures that output is relevant to the user's environment.

Show the tutorial prompt. If you select Yes, the tutorials will run consecutively, in order. If you select No, the command will exit without running any tutorials. You can run Start-PSTutorial to launch the tutorials at any time and in any order.

Show the tutorial prompt. If you select Yes, the tutorials will run consecutively, in order. If you select No, the command will exit without running any tutorials. You can run Start-PSTutorial to launch the tutorials at any time and in any order.

maml:alert.maml:para: This command has aliases of PSIntro and PSWelcome.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-PSIntro -ModuleStatus
Welcome to PowerShell!
PowerShell v7.5.4 PowerShell Documentation : https://learn.microsoft.com/powershell PowerShell on Slack : https//aka.ms/psslack PowerShell on Discord : https://aka.ms/psdiscord PowerShell Team Blog : https://devblogs.microsoft.com/powershell PowerShell Gallery : https://www.powershellgallery.com GitHub Discussion : https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/discussions
Use any of the links above to get started learning more about PowerShell. When you can, you should run Update-Help to get the latest help files for PowerShell.
Key module status:
Name Online Installed UpdateNeeded ---- ------ --------- ------------ PSReadLine 2.4.5 2.4.5 False Microsoft.PowerShell.PSResourceGet 1.1.1 1.1.1 False
All key modules are up to date.
Run Start-PSTutorial for a list of brief PowerShell tutorials.

dev:remarks.maml:para: The output will for formatted and styled using $PSStyle. The links will be clickable in Windows Terminal or similar.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Welcome to PowerShell!
PowerShell v7.5.4 PowerShell Documentation : https://learn.microsoft.com/powershell PowerShell on Slack : https//aka.ms/psslack PowerShell on Discord : https://aka.ms/psdiscord PowerShell Team Blog : https://devblogs.microsoft.com/powershell PowerShell Gallery : https://www.powershellgallery.com GitHub Discussion : https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/discussions
Use any of the links above to get started learning more about PowerShell. When you can, you should run Update-Help to get the latest help files for PowerShell.
Would you like to run a set of short interactive tutorial on essential PowerShell fundamentals? Enter Y to continue:

dev:remarks.maml:para: Launch the introduction with the tutorial prompt.

maml:description.maml:para: This command serves as a launcher for the tutorials included in the PSIntro module. You can select a tutorial topic. If you don't specify a topic, you will get a simple menu of interactive PowerShell tutorials. The tutorial consists of a combination of text and information from your host and PowerShell environment.
The tutorial will be displayed in "pages" with prompts to continue. Press `Enter` to continue or 'q' to quit. Your progress will not be saved.
Specify a tutorial topic otherwise you will be presented with a menu of topics. Valid topics are:
Specify a tutorial topic otherwise you will be presented with a menu of topics. Valid topics are:

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Start-PSTutorial
PowerShell Tutorial Menu
1 - PowerShell Essentials 2 - Get-Command 3 - Get-Help 4 - Get-Member 5 - Quit
Select a menu option [1-5]:

dev:remarks.maml:para: The menu title will be formatted using $PSStyle.
